head.title: Texas Governor Urges Smith Graduates to Rejuvenate the Political System

identified-content.org: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT STONY BROOK (SUNY)

hedline.hl1: Texas Governor Urges Smith Graduates to Rejuvenate the Political System

block.p: In her speech at Smith College's 114th commencement exercises yesterday, Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas recalled a time when "women made the coffee and men made the decisions."

But Governor Richards, addressing the 767 undergraduates and 73 graduate students on the campus of the women's college in Northampton, Mass., said that things have changed: "Men have learned to make coffee, and a few of us are in decision-making positions."
In her speech at Smith College's 114th commencement exercises yesterday, Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas recalled a time when "women made the coffee and men made the decisions."

But Governor Richards, addressing the 767 undergraduates and 73 graduate students on the campus of the women's college in Northampton, Mass., said that things have changed: "Men have learned to make coffee, and a few of us are in decision-making positions."
She urged the students to "make the difference between a system that collapses under its own tired weight and a system that is rejuvenated."
"It's not that women are better than men," said Governor Richards, who received an honorary degree from Smith. "But I hope we all accepted long ago that we are different."
She added, "When you add someone whose understanding is not intellectual, but instinctive, the whole equation changes."

Other recipients of honorary degrees were: Karen N. Horn, a banker and former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland; Zara Nelsova, a cellist and teacher at the Juilliard School; Anne P. Prache, an art historian at the Sorbonne, and Richard P. Unsworth, the headmaster of the Berkshire School. Bryn Mawr College
Representative Patricia Schroeder lamented the "public service crisis in the country" in a speech at at the 106th commencement yesterday at Bryn Mawr College.
"We have lost confidence in our government and in those who serve in it," the Colorado Democrat said. "But the power to change is only limited by the desire to act."
The commencement ceremonies began Saturday and were held over two days in Bryn Mawr, Pa.
Bryn Mawr, a women's college, awarded 308 bachelor degrees. Its graduate schools, which are co-educational, awarded 24 doctorates and 147 master's degrees. Haverford College
Faye Wattleton, the former president of Planned Parenthood, urged graduates yesterday at the 159th commencement of Haverford College to fight for women's rights.

Ms. Wattleton described the graduates as the first generation to come of age in an era of sexual and reproductive freedom. She said the right to have an abortion had become a battle about "whether women will continue to have power over our lives."
The ceremony for 306 graduating seniors was held on Haverford's campus near Philadelphia.

Haverford awarded a Doctor of Letters degree to Ms. Wattleton, who resigned from Planned Parenthood this year to start a syndicated television talk show. Robert Moses, a math teacher and former civil rights leader, and Thomas L. Friedman, the chief diplomatic correspondent for The New York Times, also received Doctor of Letters degrees.

F. Sherwood Rowland, a scientist at the University of California at Irvine who helped discover that chlorofluorocarbon gases damage the ozone layer, received a Doctor of Science degree. Duke University

Duke University awarded five honorary degrees at its 140th commencement yesterday. The ceremony for 1,534 undergraduates and 1,500 graduate students was held at the Wallace Wade Stadium at the campus in Durham, N.C.

An honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree was awarded to the commencement speaker, Marian Wright Edelman, the founder and president of the Children's Defense Fund and the first black woman admitted to the Mississippi Bar.
Also receiving honorary degrees were these:
*James D. Ebert, a developmental biologist and teacher. Mr. Ebert is noted for his research into the arrangements of cells in organisms.
*Robert R. Everett, an electrical engineer. Mr. Everett, an alumnus of Duke, has served as an adviser to the Department of Defense.
*A. Kenneth Pye, a lawyer and former chancellor, counsel and professor for Duke, who is president of Southern Methodist University.
*Elna B. Spaulding, founder of Women in Action for the Prevention of Violence and Its Causes, and a Durham County commissioner. Penn State University
Over the weekend, 7,339 students received diplomas from Pennsylvania State University in commencement ceremonies that took place on campuses around the state.
In all there were 12 graduation ceremonies. This is the 131st year the university has held commencements.
Brian Healy, a senior producer for the "CBS Evening News" in Washington, rebuked those who believe that journalists should not focus as much on such issues as violence and AIDS.
"As a journalist, I believe that this nation will solve its problems only if there is a full debate on our problems," he said yesterday in a speech to the graduates of the School of Communications.

Speakers at other colleges yesterday included Norman W. Hickey, chief administrative officer of the County of San Diego, who addressed graduates of the College of Liberal Arts, and Bryce Jordan, president emeritus of Penn State, who addressed graduates at the College of Arts and Architecture.

On Saturday, speakers included: Marian U. Coppersmith Fredman, president of the Penn State Board of Trustees, who spoke at the College of Earth and Mineral Sciences; Robert V. Waltemeyer, senior vice president of The Coca-Cola Company, who spoke at the College of Engineering; Edward R. Book, president of the Travel Industry Association of America, who addressed graduates of the College of Health and Human Development, and Helen D. Wise, Pennsylvania's deputy chief of staff for programs, who spoke at the College of Education. Tufts University
Tufts University celebrated its 136th commencement yesterday with ceremonies at which 1,540 undergraduate degrees and 370 graduate degrees were conferred.

Bernard M. Gordon, an engineer and member of the National Academy of Engineering, gave the main address. Mr. Gordon, founder of the Gordon Institute of Advanced Technology, was also awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree.
Tufts awarded 10 other honorary degrees at the ceremonies, held at the main campus in Medford, Mass. University of Virginia
Former Justice John Charles Thomas of the Virginia Supreme Court delivered the commencement address at the University of Virginia's 163d final exercises yesterday.
The university conferred 2,591 undergraduate degrees, 1,119 graduate degrees and 506 professional degrees. Mr. Thomas, a lawyer, was the first black to serve on the state's Supreme Court.
Katherine Couric, a host on the NBC program "Today," spoke at class valediction exercises on Saturday. Morehouse College
Dr. Lerone Bennett Jr., the executive editor of Ebony magazine, delivered the main address to 401 graduates yesterday at Morehouse College's 108th commencement exercise.
Dr. Bennett urged the graduates to become involved with social issues.
Morehouse College is a private four-year, liberal arts college for black men.
Spelman College
The writer Maya Angelou addressed 357 graduates at Spelman College's 91st commencement exercise, held yesterday in Atlanta.
Ms. Angelou is best known for her autobiography, "I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings."
Spelman, founded in 1881 as the Atlanta Baptist Seminary, is a liberal-arts college for black women. Adelphi University
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney spoke to 2,400 students of Adelphi University who graduated yesterday.

"This class graduates at a remarkable time in history," Mr. Cheney said in a speech at the campus in Garden City, L.I. "Four years ago, when today's college seniors were freshmen, the Communist Party still ruled Moscow, Soviet troops were still in Afghanistan, and in Moscow and Eastern Europe, dissidents were still being arrested and the Berlin Wall was still up and standing. Today, all this and more has crumbled into history."

Honorary Doctor of Law degrees were awarded to Mr. Cheney; Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the Pulitzer prize-winning historian; Max M. Kampelman, the former arms-control negotiator; Robert LeRoy Bartley, vice president and editor of The Wall Street Journal; Anna Kisselgoff, chief dance critic of The New York Times; Leon Max Lederman, director emeritus of the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory; Seth Gabriel Benardete, professor of classics at New York University; Cleanth Brooks, literary critic and scholar, and Sheldon Weinig, chairman and chief executive officer of the Materials Research Corporation. Hofstra University

The 1,700 baccalaureate and master's degree candidates at graduation ceremonies yesterday morning at Hofstra University were urged by Harrison E. Salisbury, the Pulitzer-Prize winning journalist, to consider the role they will play in a world transformed by political changes in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Salisbury was among those who received honorary doctorate degrees at the commencement at Hofstra's stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

Other honorees were Jean Dalrymple, a producer, director, actress and author; Walter J. Turnbull, the founder and president of the Harlem Boys Choir; Marilyn French, a writer; Thomas R. Pickering, ambassador-designate to India, and J. Bruce Llewellyn, chairman of Coca-Cola Bottlers of Philadelphia. University of Connecticut
The University of Connecticut awarded 1,629 advanced degrees on Saturday and 3,355 undergraduate degrees yesterday at its 109th commencement exercises at the school's campus in Storrs.

Ellen A. Peters, the chief justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, addressed the advanced degree recipients, and Cynthia Herbert Adams, a psychologist and professor of allied health professions at the university, spoke to the undergraduates. They were chosen as speakers in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the university's admission of women.

Justice Peters was among four women who were awarded honorary degrees on Saturday. The others were Mildred Spiewak Dresselhaus, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Alice H. Cook, professor emerita at the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations of Cornell University, and Robin Morgan, the editor of Ms. magazine. Fairleigh Dickinson
The president of the United Negro College Fund, William H. Gray 3d, delivered the main address yesterday at the graduation of 2,000 students from Fairleigh Dickinson University.
The university's 49th commencement ceremony was held in East Rutherford, N.J.

"There is compelling evidence that in the years just ahead, the fulfillment of the aspirations of black and other minority Americans will be fundamental to the continued success of the American Dream itself," Mr. Gray said.
Mr. Gray was awarded with an honorary Doctor of Law degree.

Other honorary degree recipients were: Robert A. Roe, United States Representative from New Jersey; Buchi Emecheta, author of historical novels, and Dr. Rosalyn Sussman Yalow, who won the Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology in 1977. SUNY-Stony Brook
The State University of New York at Stony Brook conferred 2,200 undergraduate degrees and 1,500 graduate degrees yesterday at its 32d commencement exercises on the campus in Stony Brook, L.I.
The radio journalist Nina Totenberg gave the main address. She was awarded an honorary Doctor of Letters degree.

Other recipients were Dr. Gertrude Elion, winner of the Nobel Prize in medicine, who was awarded a Doctor of Science degree, and James Simons, a mathematician and educator, awarded a Doctor of Humane Letters degree. L.I.U.-Southampton
On the 25th anniversary of the founding of Long Island University's Southampton campus, 187 undergraduates and 22 graduates received degrees.
The writer E. L. Doctorow gave the main address and received an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree. Fairfield University

Carmen Donnarumma, a politics professor at Fairfield University since the Connecticut school opened in 1947, was the main speaker at the school's 42d commencement exercises yesterday. He received an honorary degree as did Dr. John A. Barone, Fairfield's retiring provost; Thomas A. Carew, a community organizer, and Harold W. McGraw, a former chairman of McGraw-Hill Inc. Trinity College

Brendan Kennelly, an Irish poet, addressed the 511 graduates of Trinity College in Hartford at the institution's 166th commencement. Mr. Kennelly received an honorary degree, as did Steven Charleston, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Alaska; the Pulitzer Prize-winning author William Kennedy; Alice Emerson, the first female president of Emerson College; Rabbi Stanley Kessler, a figure in the civil rights movement of the 1960's; Orlando Patterson, a sociology professor at Harvard, and Joan Steitz, a professor of molecular biophysics and biochemistry at Yale.
